page.title: 13Energy - Peat digging
page.content: An act of 1828 related to the local enclosure award gives the right of those born in the Graveship of holme to dig peat from the moors. These rights are still exercised by some of the people in the area who dig peat for there own use,for they are not allowed to sell it. The laws related to peat digging are closely guarded by the constables of the Graveship of Holme,an ancient tiltle which still survies. There was some decline in peat digging in the 1960's and 70's when the the cost of other fuels-oil and gas in particular-was comparativly cheap Since that time however the digging of peat has been revived, partly as a result of increased unemployment.The peat when first dug is made up of 70% water and requires some weeks to dry.
